references: Model hijacking aims at interfering with the training process of a machine learning model and causes it to misbehave at the deployment stageÂ [17]. The FL-trained global model can be indirectly hijacked by a small number of compromised clients who share Trojaned gradients to gradually confuse the learning trajectory of FLÂ [10]. Such gradients can be generated in black-box through data poisoning. The attacker only has to poison the local training data owned by a compromised client, such as changing the ground-truth label of certain objects by dirty-label poisoningÂ [21] or implanting a backdoor to trigger the malfunctioning of a hijacked modelÂ [2, 8, 1, 20]. The FL software will take the poisoned local training data and unintentionally generate malicious gradients for sharing. With the growing number of real-world applications, recent work has begun to understand the hijacking of FL-based object detection systemsÂ [3]. As shown in TableÂ 1, the adversary can designate how the hijacked model should misdetect objects of certain classes (e.g., person) while ensuring other objects can still be precisely detected (e.g., car). This fine-grained control opens the door for an adversary to design a stealthy attack configuration to hurt the FL system yet remains hardly noticeable by the ownerÂ [5], leading to catastrophic consequences such as car crashes.

where ğ’šğ’š\boldsymbol{y} is a list of triplets, one for each object ğ’=(Class,BBox,Objn)ğ’ClassBBoxObjn\boldsymbol{o}=(\textsc{Class},\textsc{BBox},\textsc{Objn}) in the training image ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}, Class is the class label, BBox is the bounding box, and Objn is the existence of object ğ’ğ’\boldsymbol{o}. fiâ€‹(ğ’™)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™f_{i}(\boldsymbol{x}) and Fâ€‹(ğ’™)ğ¹ğ’™F(\boldsymbol{x}) denote the detected objects by the local and global models, respectively. The operator â‹ˆâ‹ˆ\bowtie indicates the degree of matching between two sets of objectsÂ [4]. Based on the three perceptual components of an object, one can formulate three poisoning strategies to designate malicious behaviors on the hijacked modelÂ [3]: (i) Class-Poison changes the class label of objects of a source class to a maliciously chosen target class without altering their bounding box locations and object existence. (ii) BBox-Poison attacks objects of certain source classes by randomly changing the size and the location of their bounding boxes without altering the class label and the object existence. (iii) Objn-Poison attacks objects of certain classes by changing their existence to non-existence. As shown in TableÂ 1, the hijacked model under Class-Poison (222nd row) mislabels the person as a potted plant in the first example and as a bird in the second example with a different attack configuration. Under BBox-Poison (333rd row), the person object is detected with a correct class label but a misaligned bounding box. Under Objn-Poison (444th row), the person vanishes in both cases. Only the designated classes suffer from performance degradation (e.g., â€œpersonâ€ in the 444th column), while the detection of objects of other irrelevant classes is not affected (e.g., â€œcarâ€ in the 555th column).

references: Trojan-agnostic Defense. We first analyze how effective STDLens is in mitigating different model hijacking attacks through perception poisoning. TableÂ 2 reports the results measured in average precisionÂ [7] of the victim source class (APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}}) under three different settings of m%percentğ‘šm\%. Given that those attacks can hijack the models to cause a drastic drop in APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} (333rd and 444th columns), STDLens offers strong defensibility against all of them (555th column).

This makes defenses using solely spatial clusteringÂ [18, 21] unable to purge all malicious clients. Even for another representative defense using spectral signaturesÂ [22], the statistical properties of malicious contributions become the same as those benign ones, as shown in FigureÂ 9(a). However, the temporal signature analysis in STDLens is, by design, resilient to such adaptive strategies, as shown in FigureÂ 8(b). Recall in EquationÂ 1 that the temporal signature of a client is computed w.r.t. each cluster, and the one with a smaller magnitude is taken to be the lower bound of malicious likelihood. Hence, the statistical characteristics of honest and malicious clients can be preserved in our temporal analysis, where malicious clients (red) have a much smaller temporal signature than honest clients (green). TableÂ 4 compares the hijacked APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} with the Î²ğ›½\beta-adaptive attack under no defense scenario (666th column) with the FL system under the protection by STDLens (777th column). A total of nine scenarios under three attacks are compared by varying the configurations of Î²ğ›½\beta from 5%percent55\% to 15%percent1515\%. We make two observations. First, under the Î²ğ›½\beta-adaptive attack, the APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} suffers from significant degradation, from 52.43%percent52.4352.43\% to 22.36%percent22.3622.36\%, even though malicious clients do not send Trojaned gradients all the time. For adaptive adversaries, the choice of Î²ğ›½\beta should be kept small as a larger Î²ğ›½\beta can notably weaken the attack effectiveness. Second, STDLens remains resilient under Î²ğ›½\beta-adaptive adversaries since it can consistently restore the APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} to at least 51.56%percent51.5651.56\% for all nine scenarios, on par with that under non-adaptive attacks (recall TableÂ 2). This is primarily because our temporal analysis is robust against such a camouflage. Integrating spatio-temporal statistics allows the identification of the malicious cluster to remain accurate under Î²ğ›½\beta-adaptive attacks.

references: Visualization. TableÂ 3 visualizes the detection results on two test examples under all three perception poisoning attacks. All three attacks fool the global model with erroneous detection: (i) Class-Poison (111st column) fools the model into mislabeling the person as a potted plant (top) or a bird (bottom), (ii) BBox-Poison (333rd column) deceives the model to recognize person objects with incorrect bounding boxes, and (iii) Objn-Poison (555th column) causes the model to detect no person objects. In comparison, STDLens successfully reinvigorates the FL system with high robustness (222nd, 444th, and 666th columns).

references: ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma}-adaptive Attacks. Another attempt to launch adaptive attacks is to wash out the spatial clustering characteristics by only poisoning Î³%percentğ›¾\gamma\% of training samples in the local dataset of a malicious client. Under this adaptive setting, the contribution from a malicious client becomes the gradient updates computed over a mixture of clean and poisoned training samples. We conduct experiments with two settings of Î³ğ›¾\gamma with results in TableÂ 5.

The Î³ğ›¾{\gamma}-adaptive attacks can bring down the APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} from 52.43%percent52.4352.43\% to 40.03%percent40.0340.03\% and 46.01%percent46.0146.01\% when we set Î³ğ›¾{\gamma} to 80%percent8080\% and 60%percent6060\%, respectively. More malicious clients fall inside the Ïƒğœ\sigma-uncertain zone, which will be incorrectly identified by defenses using only spatial clustering analysisÂ [18, 21]. Such an adaptive attack also makes spectral signaturesÂ [22] ambiguous, as the statistical properties of benign and malicious gradients overlap (FigureÂ 9(b)). For those uncertain clients, STDLens has to put the decision on hold and wait for more rounds to accumulate additional observations for making confident decisions. TableÂ 5 shows that STDLens remains robust under Î³ğ›¾{\gamma}-adaptive attacks because all malicious clients can still be identified with no false alarm. The APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} can be recovered to reach over 51.54%percent51.5451.54\%, comparable to the benign APsrcsrc{}_{\text{src}} of 52.43%percent52.4352.43\%.

references: We further compare STDLens with two existing defense methods: spatial clusteringÂ [21] and spectral signatureÂ [22], which can be extended to FL-based object detection. TableÂ 6 reports the quantitative results. All three defense solutions can detect all malicious clients over the course of FL (i.e., achieving the defense recall of 1.001.001.00). STDLens completes the detection and revocation of malicious clients between 202020 to 303030 rounds, and spatial clustering takes 303030 to 404040 rounds to detect and remove anomalies, while malicious clients can stay alive in the FL system for at most 808080 rounds with spectral signature. The main differentiation factor lies in defense precision. Even though STDLens takes a slightly longer execution time (i.e., 452452452ms with 848484ms for temporal signature analysis and 444444ms for Ïƒğœ\sigma-density inspection), it successfully identifies all malicious clients without mistakenly rejecting any benign clients (false positives), achieving a defense precision of 1.001.001.00. This allows the STDLens-protected FL to train a global object detector with high accuracy, as shown in the 222nd column in TableÂ 7. In comparison, the spatial clustering approach can reach a low precision of 0.530.530.53 under Objn-Poison, due to gradient contributions falling in the zone between the two clusters, causing ambiguity in anomaly detection. This result shows that defenses based solely on spatial clustering may not offer stable robustness. The spectral signature defense performs the worst, with a defense precision ranging from 0.260.260.26 to 0.540.540.54. It implies that while the defense can expel malicious clients, a considerable number of honest ones are also mistakenly rejected. One reason is the changing malicious population over time due to the removal of malicious clients in the early rounds. The excessive removal of clients can weaken the benign learning signal and degrade the FL-trained model, as shown in the 333rd and 444th columns in TableÂ 7.
